course.subject: COMP
course.name: Introduction to Mobile Application Development Using Android
course.description: This course provides a basic introduction to mobile application development using the Android platform. It is intended for students who have some prior programming experience, but wish to learn the basics of mobile application development. The course will introduce them to the Android SDK and development environment, Android application components: Activities and their lifecycle, UI design, Multimedia, and 2D graphics support in Android. Students explore these concepts through self-learning course materials and guided laboratory exercises. Graded P or F.
course.prerequisites: COMP 1002 OR COMP 1004 (prior to 2013-14) OR COMP 1021 OR COMP 1022P OR COMP1022Q

reviews.author: takecare
reviews.comment_content:
Basics of Android development:

1. Introduction to the Android SDK and development environment, Setting up the Android Studio environment.

2. Hello World Application, Activity Basics, UI Design: Widgets, UI Events, Event Listeners.

3. Activity lifecycle, Intents, UI Design: Widgets and Layouts, ListView.

4. 2D graphics: Canvas/Drawing into a view.

5. Multimedia: Audio playback and Audio Manager.

6. Android Networking
reviews.comment_teaching: Clear explanation of the Android development process and concepts. The TA Mr. Luke Lo is very helpful in answering your questions online and offline.
reviews.comment_grading:
5 Assignments, each of 20% towards the total points.
No final exam.

Pass or Fail. If you hand in all assignments on time, you should pass the course.
reviews.comment_workload:
In fact, it is a one-month effort.

Light. Each assignment is finished within 10 minutes.

reviews.author: YSY
reviews.comment_teaching: Hard to understand the accent. I need to read the YouTube subtitle.
reviews.comment_grading:
Only pass or fail.
5 assignments (20 scores each), no exams.
Need to gain 60% in each assignment. If you cannot get 60% in any 1 assignment, then sorry~
reviews.comment_workload:
To me, the workload is much more heavier than COMP 1029C (XoX) It would be better to know java language before studying this course.

I need a whole day to finish 1 assignment but this is a 1 credit course. (Total = 5 assignments, 1 assignment each week)

But if you can understand the accent and if your computer is fast, the workload is very light.

If your computer has only 4GB ram(as same as my notebook), then I need to say good luck to you. For a simple and short java code, the emulator needs more than an hour to run!!!!!!!!!!!!! It was very TERRIBLE! That's why I need a whole day to finish it (including watching the lecture videos).

But still, the course is worth learning.

reviews.author: Vivian Lee
reviews.comment_content: Even if reg this course in fall or spring sem, it still only study within one month and have the final exam after one month.
reviews.comment_teaching: The videos are short but kinda detail. Better look through those comment in the source code.
reviews.comment_grading:
It's only pass or fail.
Final exam taking in canvas, but need a access code so still have to take the exam with TA/ prof. 6 short questions, 10 points each. Open-book and can access Canvas while taking exam.To pass, just need to gain 40% marks in the final.
reviews.comment_workload: 4 assignments in total, one assignment per week, submit through canvas and checking by program. Those assignments are programming applications. Most of the code is provided in source code, which already taught in exercises. Only few lines of code is need to be done.

reviews.author: Atta
reviews.title: Learning the very basics of building an android application
reviews.comment_content: The content is very basic and fundamental so it is quite easy to follow. However, there are many online tutorials or videos that you can follow to achieve the same thing. I feel like the content of this course is a bit lackluster and more could be taught for this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: The TAs are all very helpful and experience in Android programming. They will help you on any part of the lab.
reviews.comment_grading: The lab assignments are simple and straight forward, so it is easy to score well on these. The other part of the course is the final exam with mostly multiple choice and short answer questions. As long as you understand what you are doing in the lab then it will be an easy pass.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is only from doing the lab assignments so it is pretty light.

reviews.author: Raj
reviews.comment_content: COMP1029A lasts for just a month and gets over before the midterm week starts. Has weekly fill in the blanks (complete the code) assignments.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Video lessons on canvas. All the topics are explained in detail.
Chapter wise quizzes are also uploaded on canvas to help one revise the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading: It's a Pass/Fail course so grading is not a problem as long as you submit all the assignments and show up for the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload. Little attention to be given towards the course just for the assignments and preparing for the final exam.

reviews.author: NightShade
reviews.title: Dear God, why?
reviews.comment_content: Detailed and well-explained. But conceptually useless for a beginner. You will be able to do everything by following the videos but will have to build the understanding on your own. (Recommended to do Java (and XML) beforehand if you want the course to add value)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor was good. Well, he has a slew of YouTube videos, regularly updated, which are clear, concise and satisfactory. Easy to understand and slow. (Accent may appear a bit heavy in the beginning.) Do not worry about SDK installation since labs have it pre-installed.
(e.g: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7__FKxrWMZw&list=PL5F07D5E9D9F3A1A4)
reviews.comment_grading:
Will pass easily even without any programming background.
passing criterion:
40% - final
60% - overall every week lab work
reviews.comment_workload: is almost nonexistent. Just follow the videos and do the lab every week for four weeks and you're done. Lab answers are video recorded so no tension. 5 arbitrary pdf readings will also be posted as weeks fly by. The finals just test the understanding.
